ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

FALLING BIRTH RATE

     1.         Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong asked the Prime Minister (a) what new measures are being considered to check the falling birth rate; and (b) what lessons can be learnt from other developed countries which have been successful in checking this trend.

 

 

     The Minister, Prime Minister's Office (Mr Lim Hng Kiang) (for the Prime Minister):  Mr Speaker, Sir, falling birth rate is a serious problem.  It is not a new problem but it is a complex problem.  As Deputy Prime Minister Mr Lee Hsien Loong said, he will address this issue in his Budget Speech later on.  I would like to urge Members to be patient, listen to DPM's speech, and I am sure we will have ample opportunities to debate this issue during the Budget debate as well as during the Committee of Supply.

Column: 406

HEALTHCARE COSTS

2.  Dr Lily Neo asked the Acting Minister for Health what are the steps taken or will be taken by his Ministry to help contain the healthcare costs in the public sector.

     The Acting Minister for Health (Mr Khaw Boon Wan):  Mr Speaker, Sir, managing medical inflation so that healthcare costs do not run wild is one of my Ministry's priorities.

 

         It is, however, not possible to eliminate medical inflation and keep healthcare cost constant.  This is because healthcare is both labour and capital intensive and it will not be realistic to expect healthcare workers to have no wage increases.

 

Column: 407

       However, it is possible to manage healthcare costs with a view to keep medical inflation within affordable limits.  But it requires major and continuous efforts, from all the stakeholders in the healthcare sector: doctors, hospitals, patients and their loved ones.

 

        To understand this phenomenon, we need to first know the key drivers behind medical inflation.  There are several.  But I will highlight three: shortage of skilled manpower, rapid introduction of new medical technology and rising expectation from patients.

 

        While skilled manpower and new medical technology have led to significant improvements in medical outcome, the results come with a large price tag.  At the same time, increasing affluence of Singaporeans and greater awareness of technological advances in medicine have led to higher expectations from patients in terms of the care and kind of treatment they should receive.  

 

         Against this backdrop, the challenge is to keep pace with medical advancement, but at a rate which the society as a whole is willing to pay.  Inevitably and realistically, some sort of rationing has to be done and patient expectations need to be managed.

 

         It is little wonder that rising healthcare cost is a global phenomenon.  Indeed, relative to many other developed countries, Singapore has fared not too badly.

 

        I will not be able to give a comprehensive account of all our steps in managing medical inflation.  But broadly, I will group them into six major thrusts.

 

        First, emphasise personal responsibility in healthcare.  Government can only provide healthcare services, but good health has to be attained by individuals. 

Column: 408

The most effective way to manage medical inflation is to keep Singaporeans healthy.  That is why it is so important for all Singaporeans to lead a healthy lifestyle, thus avoiding illness and hospitalisation.  On this score, as Members of Parliament, we have an important role to play.  I think we should walk-the-talk and be shining examples of what healthy lifestyle is all about.  Incidentally, this Sunday, I will be taking part in a 5-km run to raise money for SSO.  Mr Speaker and our colleagues, especially those in the GPC on Health, are most welcome to join in the run.  We will kill several birds with one stone - promote health and support the arts and sports.

 

        Second, increase supply of skilled manpower, especially specialists and nurses, to match rising demand.  Without this, any prolonged shortage must inevitably lead to excessive wage increases.  We are thus expanding our training capacity, but meanwhile we will mount external recruitment to augment our local supply.

 

      Third, our healthcare providers, especially the hospitals, must squeeze as much productivity as they can out of their resources.  They must strive to produce more with less.  This is a continuous endeavour.

 

       Some examples of their recent effort: the clusters have consolidated their IT systems management and support, reducing IT manpower requirements by 15%. TTSH and NUH have combined their Central Sterile Supplies Department (CSSD) services at TTSH.  If I am not mistaken, I recall reading the Hansard record when a few years back, Dr Lily Neo indeed made such a suggestion about combining CSSD to reap the economies of scale.  I am pleased to announce that her suggestion has been put into practice.  This has saved $600,000 in capital expense and $130,000 a year in operating expense.

 

Column: 409

       Other consolidations such as Finance are being explored. Further savings are expected from outsourcing of services, such as catering and maintenance/engineering.  I also encourage them to consider cross-border outsourcing where it makes sense. 

 

        Fourth, I have urged the clusters to collaborate for mutual benefit. The objective is to avoid dysfunctional competition and costly duplication.

 

        One example.  The clusters have derived significant savings in the procurement of medical supplies, drugs and services through group procurement. The aim is to source for lower cost alternatives and achieve better economies of scale through product standardisation and consolidation of purchase volumes.

 

        Fifth, the doctors are reviewing their clinical practices. The aim is to maximise health outcome with minimum resources.  This includes efforts to ensure that care is rendered at the most appropriate setting.

 

        One example. My Ministry has been working with the clusters to develop the Singapore National Asthma Programme that aims to reduce hospital admissions and move treatment to the primary care level.

 

        The clusters have also actively sought to decrease the length of stay in hospitals by promoting day surgery, same day admission for surgery as well as a seamless transition to step down care.

 

        Other examples.  The clusters have introduced prescribing protocols that encourage the use of generic drugs.  The increasing use of electronic medical records would further help to save costs by avoiding repeat tests being carried out on the same patient as the hospital doctor

Column: 410

can then access test results already done in the polyclinic and vice versa.

 

      Finally, moderate public expectations.  Patients and their loved ones quite naturally will demand the best possible care.  While we will always do our best, we must be realistic about our ability to match rising expectations and demand, especially if the patients are unwilling to pay for the incremental cost of service enhancement.

 

     The best way forward is to ensure a range of services available at different prices and to push out such information into the public domain.  That is why my Ministry has since last year published hospital bill size statistics for common medical conditions on our website. By promoting greater transparency of hospital charges, hospitals are now able to compare the effectiveness of their cost management initiatives, not only against their own historical costs but also against that of other hospitals. As I explained to the House recently, this allows the hospitals to ask intelligent questions if their charges are significantly different from others, and take proactive steps to cut waste and reduce costs.  

 

        In summary, we will continue to strive to cut inefficiency and frills without compromising the quality of medical care.   We must, however, be realistic as to the extent to which hospitals can keep cost down while continuing to maintain healthcare standards. If we expect the best treatment and diagnostics, short queues and good service, costs will increase and patients must be prepared to bear part of the cost for it.

 

       I would like to assure Singaporeans, however, for essential services, no Singaporean will be denied such care because of their financial status.

 

 

     Dr Lily Neo (Jalan Besar):  May I ask the Minister whether our present policy of

Column: 411

encouraging competition between hospital clusters and sectors is effective in controlling healthcare cost inflation?  Should there not be a review to favour more centralised control over healthcare resources for better control of healthcare patients?

     Mr Khaw Boon Wan:  Mr Speaker, Sir, I recall making a fairly extensive speech last year about this whole topic.  Obviously, the solution is not the extreme - either complete centralisation, going back to the good old days of the Ministry of Health when I started my career as a young officer, or to go all the way to compete and duplicate.   Like all things, take the middle path and pick the best of both worlds.  There are values in centralisation but there are also values in competition.

 

     My challenge to the clusters is:  compete by all means but compete to produce more with less.  But where it makes sense to collaborate, please do so.  Recently, when SingHealth cluster started a public cord blood bank, I sat tight to see what was the reaction.  Not bad.  A few days later, I received an email from the other cluster saying that they would back this project, instead of duplicating a second cord blood bank.

     Dr Lily Neo:  May I ask the Minister on the reasons why public hospitals compete against one another for patients and market share?  Has this resulted in supply-induced demand for services in our public hospitals?  Are public hospitals too focused on cost recovery and is it correct for public hospitals to spend money branding themselves to attract more patients?

     Mr Khaw Boon Wan:  Mr Speaker, Sir, in the same speech that I talked about a few minutes ago, I also covered this topic.  I think I should send the speech to Dr Lily Neo. 

 

Column: 412

     The competition for market share has to be taken in its right spirit.  I advised the clusters that, stretching the argument, I would clap hands if their workload shrinks, but not if their workload expands.  Of course, provided they achieve this not because of lousy service or unsafe standards when everybody runs away from them, like SARS.  But, if despite giving good service and, let us say, all the parliamentarians help me out in promoting healthy lifestyles and after a while, illnesses drop, so that patient load comes down or if good economic management leads to strong growth, and more and more people can afford unsubsidised private hospitals and would rather not spend time waiting in the queue of public hospitals, and our market share shrinks, I clap hands.  That is the spirit I bring to this whole issue about market share.

 

 


     Mr Sin Boon Ann (Tampines):  Sir, in a competitive environment, I would like to ask the Minister who decides when he collaborates and when he competes.  Presumably, it is the Government and if the Government decides finally who competes and when you collaborate, can you effectively have free market forces operating in the healthcare industry in such a context?

     Mr Khaw Boon Wan:  It is for the players to decide.  It is not possible for the Ministry of Health, or Parliament, to micro-manage and decide, "Ok, you do this, you do that."  The communist countries tried to do that and, of course, they discovered that they could not achieve the desired outcome through that way.  What we can do is to make sure that at the macro level, we have the right parameters in place.  What are those parameters?  How much subvention am I  prepared to give to the hospitals?  What are those expectations about fee increases?  And, of course, as shareholders of both clusters, our expectations are that they must balance

Column: 413

their accounts.  You cannot chalk up and build up losses perennially. 

 

     That is why last year, I sat down with them and said that it was a bad time to raise fees, although I knew they were under a lot of pressure because they would otherwise be losing money.  I said, "No.  Learn to live within your means.  Cut your costs."  In any case, we are no longer providing them with very small sums.  As you know, the Ministry of Health's budget is now more than $2 billion.  I put out this paper last week where it showed a subsidy of more than $1 billion.  This is not chicken-feed.  So the question is, as a trustee of taxpayer's money, our job is to decide how best to stretch this budget.  The way to do so is to make sure they spend their money properly and if they can collaborate to bring their costs down, do so.  If they can outsource to private players in Singapore or even outside of Singapore, do so.

 

     The other day I met a pathologist from Tan Tock Seng and he was telling me that our storage cost for pathology samples cannot beat Johor Baru.  I do not know exactly what he is talking about.  But he seems to make sense.  He said that we could store them in Johor Baru where land cost is low.  So there are possibilities of that kind.  I think we should let the players decide, they are paid to do so, to balance their accounts, provide the best possible service with the budget that they have, to stretch the budget as much as they can to produce the outcome that the society needs.

     Dr Lily Neo rose  -

     Mr Speaker:   May I remind Members we have 16 Questions to deal with today.  Dr Neo.

     Dr Lily Neo:  Thank you, Mr Speaker.  Following the Minister's early mention on

Column: 414

subsidies, may I ask the Minister on this subvention to Government hospitals?  Has there been a decrease in subvention in relation to hospital admissions?  Is it correct that in the years 2000 to 2003, public hospitals received less amount of subsidies but they had greater numbers of hospital admissions?  Do public hospitals pass on the imbalance of subsidies and operating costs to patients, thus raising the burden for patients in healthcare expenditure?

     Mr Khaw Boon Wan:  The short answer is no.  I think subvention has increased from $759 million in 1998 to $1.187 billion in 2002.   This is the total quantum.  As compared to volumes, I do not know.  Healthcare is complicated because it is not just numbers.  Every year, the case mix is different.  Every patient is different.  I witnessed my wife's three pregnancies and I was with her when the babies were delivered at the labour ward.  Every delivery is different, although the same woman, the same husband.  So let alone, illnesses.  Yes, last year, we had 10,000 admissions; this year, 10,000 admissions, but if the case mix is different, the outcome and the resources needed would be different.

Column: 414

STUDENTS FOUND WITH PORNOGRAPHIC VCDS

     3.  Mr Iswaran asked the Acting Minister for Education in light of the recent incident at Kent Ridge Secondary School, where students were found with pornographic VCDs and the incidents were reported to the Police, what guidelines on how to handle such incidents have been issued to schools by the Ministry.

 

     The Acting Minister for Education (Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam):  Mr Speaker, Sir, MOE has given schools broad guidelines on the approaches and actions they could adopt in managing student discipline.  These guidelines set out the

Column: 415

positive, proactive approach schools should adopt in handling discipline, as part of their broader efforts to help our young become responsible, thinking citizens.

  

   The guidelines recommend the development of a coherent, whole-school framework for managing discipline.  This comprises measures ranging from the preventive to the corrective  -  in other words, from educating the students to counselling them and to taking disciplinary actions. The guidelines  provide schools with examples of programmes and strategies that they can adopt  to manage discipline in their schools.  They also advise schools on how they can work in partnership with parents, and obtain the assistance of external agencies, such as the VWOs, self-help groups and the Police. 

 

   While the MOE guidelines help achieve  a broad consistency of principles and approaches in managing discipline amongst  our schools, each school has to decide on  its own specific  approaches. This will depend on the nature of its student body and the history of student discipline in the school.

 

   

    Schools also have to decide  on the actions most appropriate in each situation, such as  counselling the students involved, disciplining them within the school, referring them to other agencies for further counselling and help, or reporting the matter to the Police. In particular, a decision on whether to call in the Police has to be made by the principal,  and that will depend on the severity of the offence, the scale of the problem,  and the willingness of the students involved to cooperate. These are ground decisions that the principal is in the best position to make.

     Assoc. Prof. Ngiam Tee Liang (Nominated Member):  Mr Speaker, Sir, the guidelines from the Ministry would probably set the broad parameters and depending on the experience of the

Column: 416

principals (including new principals coming in), what additional guidance is given so that they have an idea of how to operationalise those guidelines?  Otherwise, I think maybe it is a situation of not having opportunities to learn from each other and, although principals are trying their best, it could be a hit-and-miss affair.

     Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam:  First, the guidelines themselves are actually quite useful.  We provide examples of the types of problems and offences within the school that perhaps the school can handle on its own and how it should go about handling them.  We also provide the examples of the more serious matters which would be referred to external agencies, including the Police.  I think we prepare our principals, including our young principals, quite well.  They all go through not just training on how to be a good school leader, but we also engage them in a fair bit of sharing of best practices.  They meet often with their cluster's Superintendent, and with the people in the Ministry.  There is a fair bit of sharing within the community of principals themselves.  Young principals do not come in totally fresh.  They have already been acquainted with the ways of leadership in a school and once they are in leadership, they are able to tap on views and perspectives from others within the school leadership community.

     Mr S Iswaran (West Coast):  Sir, I accept the Minister's explanation that we entrust considerable discretion and responsibility in the hands of our principals.  That is quite correct.  But the corollary is that there will be some variability in the way that discretion is exercised across schools and we can accept that to a limit.  But on matters as serious as Police reports, can the Ministry perhaps be more prescriptive as to the steps that the principals must take before taking such a serious decision which can have a lifelong impact on the students?

Column: 417

     Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam:  Variability is what is to be expected because, as Mr Khaw Boon Wan says, every birth is different.  Every school is different.  Student population is different, the history of the problem is different and each instance is different.  So I would not want to constrain schools with too prescriptive an approach.  We already provide very useful guidelines, with lots of illustrations on how to handle the problems.  But the principal is the person on the ground and he or she has to decide.  The Ministry is not in a position to prescribe how each and every situation should be decided upon.  It is just not possible.  Not only is it not possible, it is not desirable either.

 

     If we want strong schools with strong leaders, we cannot have them referring to a detailed rule book each and every time something happens, we cannot have them second guessing the Ministry, we cannot have them calling up the Ministry to ask: what should I do in this instance?  We do not get strong schools and strong principals if we do that.  We now have strong schools and, by and large, we have very good principals.  I think to keep it that way, we have got to leave the decisions on these matters with them.  These are the ground decisions they are in the best position to make.  If they make decisions that are quite unreasonable, then the Ministry will intervene.   But in this instance, the decision was not unreasonable, and that is why the Ministry supported the decision of the principal.

     Ms Braema Mathiaparanam (Nominated Member):  Can I ask the Minister then, since we do believe that principals must have the autonomy to exercise what they feel is the best ground decision, how are principals chosen, perhaps what kind of track record do we look at to ensure that we have got a good principal who knows how to use discretion in such matters?

Column: 418

     Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam:  There is no cookie-cutter approach to selecting a principal.  This is like leadership in other areas that we are familiar with, how you spot a person with leadership abilities.  It is also, in the school context, about people who know what teaching is about, what nurturing students is really about, people with a certain sense of care and compassion.  Our principals are basically people with a good sense of how young individuals grow.  We take great pains to identify potential school leaders early in their careers and we check our assessments as they go through their careers.  We go to great lengths to do so and put them through various projects and courses where we can also come up with further assessments as to who would make a good principal.  It is not a perfect process, but it is not working too badly.    

Column: 418

SCHOOL FUND-RAISING PROJECTS

(Guidelines)

     4.  Mr Ang Mong Seng asked the Acting Minister for Education whether there are any regulations or guidelines on  fund-raising projects for school principals to follow  in order to spare students from committing too much of their study time, effort and money to such projects.

     The Minister of State for Education (Mr Chan Soo Sen) (for the Acting Minister for Education):  Mr Speaker, Sir, principals are responsible for deciding on fund-raising activities of their schools.  They can decide on the type and timing of the fund-raising activities.  However, MOE does have guidelines to ensure that students are not committed to too many of such activities.  As a guide, each student should not participate in more than two fund-raising activities a year, and that is in addition to Sharity Day for primary school students and Youth Day Collection for secondary school students, both of these collections are meant for the Community Chest.

Column: 419

     Mr Ang Mong Seng (Hong Kah):  Can I ask the Minister of State whether he can enlighten the House in the years 2002 and 2003, the total number of fund-raising projects and the total sums we had raised, and how many are for school projects and how many are for outside the school projects?

     Mr Chan Soo Sen:  As I said, principals are responsible for deciding on fund-raising activities of their schools.  The Ministry does not require them to seek approval from the Ministry before they proceed.  All they need to do is just observe the general guidelines.  So I am afraid we have no figures on how many fund-raising activities overall and how much has been raised.  But we do believe that all these activities are for the benefit of the schools.

Importance of Sound Public Finance

One of the most important contributions any government can make to economic growth and resilience is to put public finances on a sound footing.  A balanced budget and a trim and efficient public sector will make for stable macroeconomic conditions and a pro-business climate. Fiscal prudence has been a hallmark of Singa­pore's economic management.   Some people accuse us of being too prudent, but we must continue to maintain fiscal prudence, despite stronger spending pressures and tighter budgets.  We will spend more in a downturn if we need to, even if it means going into temporary deficit, as we have done in the past two years. But we must never fall into the trap of structural budget deficits, with a permanent shortfall of revenue. On average, over the course of the business cycle, we aim to accumulate a modest surplus, putting aside something in good years so that we have some savings to draw upon in bad years.

Medisave for Self-Employed

     Originally the self-employed did not fall within this 3M framework, because they did not contribute to Medisave.   But in 1992 the Government amended the CPF Act to require self-employed individuals who earn above a certain salary - currently $6,000 a year - to make compulsory contributions to their Medisave accounts.   We wanted to make sure that the self-employed regularly put aside savings for their health needs and not expose themselves to unnecessary financial risk when they or their families fall ill.

Singapore is what it is today because it has been a land of opportunity for enterprising people from all over Asia.  Our attractions are unique.  We are at the crossroads of East and West, a modern, cosmopolitan city connected to the world of finance and business, yet rooted in the ancient cultures of our forebears.   We offer a vibrant economy where people can earn a good living, a stable society where they can raise strong families, and opportunities for all to build a brighter future.   And now with Asia on the rise, we must remake Singapore as a land of opportunity.

A key element of our efforts to remake Singapore is a globally competitive tax

STUDIO APARTMENTS FOR THE ELDERLY

     12.   Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan asked the Minister for National Development (a) how many studio apartments for the elderly have been built by HDB since the introduction of the scheme; (b) how many have been taken up; (c) whether his Ministry intends to continue to provide this form of housing for the elderly; and (d) what other measures will be introduced to cater to the housing needs of the elderly.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan:

     Since the launch of the Studio Apartment (SA) scheme in 1998, HDB has built a total of 936 SAs in standalone blocks under the pilot phase. About 96% of the units are currently occupied. The remaining units were returned to HDB by their former owners. HDB will re-offer them for sale to eligible applicants.

 

     In view of the favourable response to the pilot batch of SAs, HDB will be building new SAs to meet the housing needs of the elderly. These will be integrated with other HDB flat types in the same block to encourage more social interaction between the elderly and younger residents. 300 such units are being built at Selective En-bloc Redevelopment Scheme (SERS) replacement sites in Geylang, Bukit Merah and Queenstown. They are currently being offered for sale to SERS lessees and the balance units will be offered to the public at the end of 2004.  HDB will gauge the response to these new integrated SAs before deciding on its future plans for SAs.

 

     Besides SAs, the elderly in Singapore have other housing options. They can buy various types of HDB flats according to their preference and financial situation.  Through HDB's upgrading programmes, HDB flats are made more elderly friendly to enable our elderly to remain in their own homes.  Elderly households with lower incomes can apply to rent a flat from HDB at subsidised rates.  We will continue to regularly review our housing policies for the elderly to ensure that they are relevant and sufficient to meet the needs of our ageing population.

     14.   Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong asked the Minister for Transport what is being done by his Ministry to monitor and improve the service of taxi companies and taxis, especially the "On Call" taxis which pick and choose fares.

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong:

     Today, we have some 40,000 taxi drivers driving over 19,000 taxis on our roads. I am pleased to say that on the whole, our taxi drivers have upheld excellent service standards.

 

Column: 507

     Some commuters have complained that taxi drivers are abusing the "On Call" signs to pick and choose fares.  To put this matter in perspective, let me explain that 62% of our taxis are fitted with automatic "On Call" signs.  This means that the "On Call" signs of these taxis are controlled by a central dispatch system, and cannot be manipulated by taxi drivers themselves. As for the rest, we have strict measures to curb such possible errant behaviour by drivers.

 

 

   Members would recall that last June, LTA put in place the Vocational Licence Points System (VLPS) to regulate the conduct of taxi drivers.  Under the VLPS, the penalties (ie, fines and demerit points) for various offences are spelt out in a transparent manner, together with guidelines on suspending or revoking vocational licences arising from the offences. Abusing the "On Call" sign to refuse a customer is an offence that LTA views seriously.  Under the VLPS, taxi drivers who refuse to pick up customers without a valid reason will be fined $100, and given 3 demerit points. A taxi driver's vocational licence will be suspended once he accumulates 6 or more demerit points.

 

 

    I would also like to assure the Member that LTA will continue to monitor the Quality of Service (QoS) performance of the taxi companies closely, under the Taxi Operator Licensing regime, to ensure high standards of service to commuters.

There have been many reported instances of taxi drivers who have gone the extra mile to provide good service to their commuters.  One example, which was published on the Forum page (19th December 2003), is of a taxi driver who drove all the way from Jurong to Pasir Ris to return a purse and a bag of groceries that a passenger had earlier left behind in his taxi.  Many other grateful commuters have similarly written letters to the Forum page to commend taxi drivers for their service.  I would like to urge commuters to come forward to compliment taxi drivers where this is due, as this is yet another way to spur service improvement in the sector.
